questions.text: Drugs used in postpartum hemorrhage are: Misoprostol Dinoprostone Prostaglandin F2 alpha Oxytocin Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.correct_answer: D. If all four (1, 2, 3, & 4) are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If all four (1, 2, 3, & 4) are correct Oxytocin is drug of choice for postpartum hemorrhage Least effective- dinoprostone (used locally) as it is not UTEROTONIC in nature. Given by intramuscular injection Drugs for the management of Immediate Postpartum Hemorrhage DRUG DOSE COMMENTS Oxytocin * 20-40 units in 1 L of crystalloid initially infused at 200-500 mL/hr and then titrate to sustain uterine contractions and control hemorrhage Do not administer as an IV bolus. First-line therapy. If IV access is unavailable, may use 10 units IM Methylergonovine maleate or ergonovine maleate 0.2 mg IM Avoid in patients with hypertensive disease, including preeclampsia Carboprost tromethamine 0.25 mg IM Repeat q15min until uterine hemorrhage is controlled or a maximum dose of 2 mg Concurrent use of antiemetics and antidiarrheals recommended to control side effects Misoprostol (Cytotec) 800-1000 µg PR Single dose; can give PO. May cause tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding digoxin: Earliest side effect is nausea and vomiting Causes nonspecific colour vision It causes Hypomagnesemia Hypokalemia is associated with increased toxicity Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If 1, 2 and 4 are correct

Highyeild:

MC toxicity - nausea vomiting (Earliest to be seen in digoxin toxicity) MC arrhythmia – ventricular bigeminy Hypomagnesemia is not caused by digoxin rather if present, it increases the risk of digoxin toxicity. Early nonspecific color vision is seen which later converts to Xanthopsia (i.e. Yellow colour vision). Digoxin has high volume of distribution and it may cause neurological symptoms Potassium and digoxin compete for the same site and hypokalemia can result in toxicity of digoxin.

Table:

#MANTRA DIGOXIN-Lanoxin Mechanism • A purified cardiac glycoside extracted from the foxglove plant, Digitalis lanata • Directly inhibits Na'/K' ATPase intracellular Na→ inhibits Na*/Ca" exchanger →↑ intracellular Ca ↑ Ca" release from sarcoplasmic reticulum →↑ contractile force (positive inotropy) • Also, digoxin ↑ vagal activity & ↓ AV node conduction →↓ heart rate Clinical Use • Congestive heart failure (by contractility) • Atrial fibrillation (by↓ AV node conduction) Adverse Effects • Cholinergic effects ("dig delirium") - nausea, V+D, blurry yellow-green vision/halos • Atrial tachycardia & AV block • Hyperkalemia • Toxic doses → arrhythmias DIGOXIN: Indications: Atrial fibrillation Heart failure Contraindications: Ventricular fibrillation Ventricular tachycardia Arrhythmia Side effects: Pulsus bigeminous (2pulses+gan)

questions.text: A 53 years old is found to be hypertensive stage 2 without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start?
questions.explanation:

Highyeild:

Drug of choice for hypertension – Thiazide diuretics Rest of drugs are - ACE inhibitor/ARB, calcium channel blockers, diuretics Chlorthalidone is thiazide and hence used for starting treatment for a patient without comorbidity. Furosemide is loop diuretic and spironolactone and triamterene is potassium sparing diuretic

questions.text: SGLT-2 inhibitors are recently used for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following are the rare but serious side effects? Ketoacidosis Fournier gangrene Urosepsis Angioedema Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If 1, 2, 3 are correct

Highyeild:

SGLT2 Inhibitor Mechanism of Action SGLT2 inhibitors work in the proximal tubules of the kidney to block the reabsorption of glucose back into the blood system, thus reducing blood glucose levels DKA is a severe metabolic condition usually characterized by hyperglycemia resulting from a relative insulin deficient state SGLT-2 inhibitors Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin These drugs are related to urinary infection so urosepsis is seen Fournier gangrene is also a side-effect which is genital infection Ketoacidosis can occur in these patients even if the blood sugar levels are under control Angioedema is mainly seen with ACE inhibitor / DPP4 inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the mentioned drug most commonly causes acute liver failure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paracetamol

Highyeild:

PARACETAMOL POISONING: Hepatic damage: more than 150mg per kg Clinical feature: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort In untreated patient's developing liver damage, vomiting continues beyond 12 hrs and there is tenderness over the liver, jaundice,hepatic encephalopathy, loin pain, haematuria, proteinuria suggest renal failure. Investigation:LFTs, liver enzyme,INR(international normalised ratio) LFT: Alanine transaminase (ALT), also called Serum Glutamic Pyruvate Transaminase (SGPT) or Alanine aminotransferase (ALAT) Aspartate transaminase (AST) also called Serum Glutamic Oxaloacetic Transaminase (SGOT) or aspartate aminotransferase (ASAT) Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) Bilirubin (direct and total) Most common drug implicated in drug poisoning therefore causing liver failure is paracetamol Usually seen in alcoholics or in those who have overdosed for suicidal attempt.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.warfarin is an oral anticoagulant which helps prevent the formation of harmful blood clots in the legs, lungs, brain, and heart. Option B. Tetracycline is an oral antibiotic in the tetracyclines family of medications, used to treat a number of infections, including acne, cholera, brucellosis, plague, malaria, and syphilis. Common side effects include vomiting, diarrhea, rash, and loss of appetite. Option D. Valproate belongs to a group of medicines called anti-epileptics. It is used to treat two conditions – epilepsy and bipolar disorder. It also helps in the prevention of migraine. This way it prevents extreme mood swings and abnormal brain signals that trigger seizures (fits).

questions.text: There is outbreak of MRSA in hospital. It was found that the nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization in anterior nares. What is best treatment?
questions.explanation:

Topical Mupirocin

Highyeild:

MOA OF MUPIROCIN Binds to isoleucyl tRNA synthetase Prevents incorporation of isoleucine into bacterial protiens Drug of choice for MRSA - I/V vancomycin Drug of choice for carrier - mupirocin/ bacitracin

Option C. colistin also known as polymyxin E, is an antibiotic medication used as a last-resort treatment for multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections including pneumonia.
